results.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert Adam Whitely / Felicia JollyGoodFellow (Guy Pearce) costume
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: While most of the Oscar-winning costumes in The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert (1994) were made with small budgets and creative solutions, the pom-poms on this iconic wattle dress were made by inmates at the Long Bay Correctional Complex.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

results.title: Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) Power Glove
results.material_description: Sollid and flexible plastic with cloth/material backing.
results.brief_description:
“I love the Power Glove… it’s so bad.” – The Wizard

In 1989, ‘bad’ was slang for cool and there was nothing cooler than the Power Glove. At least, that’s what a generation who believed its marketing thought. Developed by Mattel as an alternative controller for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES), the Power Glove promised to bridge the human-machine divide through early VR mechanics. Just slip on the glove to control your favourite NES games. Except it didn’t really work - well, not in the seamless way the Nintendo-produced movie The Wizard (1989) promised. The Power Glove’s prototype, the DataGlove, did work, but to be affordable for consumers it was simplified and ended up just… so bad.
results.description:
“I love the Power Glove… it’s so bad.” – Lucas (Jackey Vinson) in The Wizard.

In 1989, ‘bad’ was slang for cool and there was nothing cooler than the Power Glove. At least, that’s what a generation who believed its marketing thought. Developed by Mattel as an alternative controller for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES), the Power Glove promised to bridge the human-machine divide through early VR mechanics. Just slip on the glove to control your favourite NES games. Except it didn’t really work - well, not in the seamless way the Nintendo-produced movie The Wizard (1989) promised. The Power Glove’s prototype, the DataGlove, did work, but to be affordable for consumers it was simplified and ended up just… so bad.

“I love the Power Glove… it’s so bad.” – Lucas (Jackey Vinson) in The Wizard.

In 1989, ‘bad’ was slang for cool and there was nothing cooler than the Power Glove. At least, that’s what a generation who believed its marketing thought. Developed by Mattel as an alternative controller for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES), the Power Glove promised to bridge the human-machine divide through early VR mechanics. Just slip on the glove to control your favourite NES games. Except it didn’t really work - well, not in the seamless way the Nintendo-produced movie The Wizard (1989) promised. The Power Glove’s prototype, the DataGlove, did work, but to be affordable for consumers it was simplified and ended up just… so bad.

results.title: National Portable Video Recorder NV-3085
results.brief_description: Portable reel to reel sound recorder. Heavy, comprised mostly of metal and plastic. Used in tandem with National Panasonic Portapak WV 3085 camera to record sound.
